questions.text: When osteomyelitis is disseminated via hematogenous route, the most affected part of bone is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metaphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The metaphysis is the most common site for hematogenous osteomyelitis due to its rich blood supply and slower blood flow, which allows bacteria to become trapped and cause infection.
  • ➤ The metaphysis is the most common site for hematogenous osteomyelitis due to its rich blood supply and slower blood flow, which allows bacteria to become trapped and cause infection.

questions.text: Non-healing sinus is a common clinical feature in chronic osteomyelitis. Most common cause of this presentation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presence of sequestrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of sequestrum is the most common cause of non-healing sinuses in chronic osteomyelitis because the sequestrum represents dead bone that cannot heal, providing a continuous source of infection.
  • ➤ The presence of sequestrum is the most common cause of non-healing sinuses in chronic osteomyelitis because the sequestrum represents dead bone that cannot heal, providing a continuous source of infection.

questions.text: True about Brodie’s abscess is/are:

options.label: A
options.text: Long standing localized pyogenic abscess in bone

options.label: B
options.text: Common sites are upper end of tibia & lower end of femur

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brodie's abscess is indeed a chronic or long-standing localized pyogenic abscess. The upper tibia and lower femur are the most common sites for Brodie’s abscess. It presents with deep, boring pain, which is a characteristic feature.
  • ➤ Brodie's abscess is indeed a chronic or long-standing localized pyogenic abscess.
  • ➤ The upper tibia and lower femur are the most common sites for Brodie’s abscess.
  • ➤ It presents with deep, boring pain, which is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with multiple swellings and multiple brown rashes. She has increased uptake on bone scan over femur, skull and ribs. Biomechanical parameters are abnormal. She also has a history of hypothyroidism. Following is her x-ray. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) McCune Albright syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of skeletal involvement, café-au-lait spots, hypothyroidism, and abnormal bone scan findings points to McCune-Albright syndrome.
  • ➤ The combination of skeletal involvement, café-au-lait spots, hypothyroidism, and abnormal bone scan findings points to McCune-Albright syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about the given image?

options.label: B
options.text: May be caused due to pin prick injury

options.label: D
options.text: May be treated initially by antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: C. Causative organism is staph. Epidermis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Causative organism is staph. Epidermis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus epidermidis is more often implicated in infections related to indwelling devices and is less virulent. It is not the primary cause of felon.
  • ➤ Staphylococcus epidermidis is more often implicated in infections related to indwelling devices and is less virulent.
  • ➤ It is not the primary cause of felon.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient is presenting with chief complains of tingling and numbness in lateral three and half fingers. What can be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pronator teres syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pronator Teres Syndrome involves median nerve compression at the forearm, leading to symptoms in the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index, middle, and part of the ring finger).
  • ➤ Pronator Teres Syndrome involves median nerve compression at the forearm, leading to symptoms in the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index, middle, and part of the ring finger).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy sustained fracture lateral condyle of humerus, gradually developed elbow deformity. Which of the following is the likely outcome?
questions.correct_answer: D. Inability to adduct the fingers
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inability to adduct the fingers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inability to Adduct the Fingers is related to ulnar nerve injury. While less directly related, significant elbow deformities could potentially involve the ulnar nerve.
  • ➤ Inability to Adduct the Fingers is related to ulnar nerve injury.
  • ➤ Inability to Adduct the Fingers
  • ➤ While less directly related, significant elbow deformities could potentially involve the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Deforming polyarthritis is associated with all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Behçet's syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Behçet's syndrome typically presents with non-deforming arthritis that is often transient and does not cause significant joint destruction over time.
  • ➤ Behçet's syndrome typically presents with non-deforming arthritis that is often transient and does not cause significant joint destruction over time.

questions.text: Kohler’s disease is osteochondrosis of which of the following bone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Navicular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kohler's disease affects the navicular bone in the foot. It is the osteochondrosis of the navicular bone.
  • ➤ Kohler's disease affects the navicular bone in the foot.
  • ➤ It is the osteochondrosis of the navicular bone.

questions.text: Idiopathic scoliosis is:

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral curvature with rotation of spine

questions.correct_answer: C. Lateral curvature with rotation of spine
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lateral curvature with rotation of spine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral curvature with rotation of the spine is the most accurate and complete description of idiopathic scoliosis. Other options are incomplete as they fail to address both key components of scoliosis, while Option D. describes a different spinal deformity altogether.
  • ➤ Lateral curvature with rotation of the spine is the most accurate and complete description of idiopathic scoliosis.
  • ➤ Other options are incomplete as they fail to address both key components of scoliosis, while Option D. describes a different spinal deformity altogether.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man sustained a shoulder injury and presented with swelling of shoulder. X-ray is shown below. Which is/are the ligament(s) injured?
questions.correct_answer: D. Both Acromioclavicular and Coracoclavicular ligament
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both Acromioclavicular and Coracoclavicular ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both Acromioclavicular and Coracoclavicular ligaments are the primary structures involved in AC joint separation or dislocation, which is a common shoulder injury caused by trauma, especially when both ligaments are torn.
  • ➤ Both Acromioclavicular and Coracoclavicular ligaments are the primary structures involved in AC joint separation or dislocation, which is a common shoulder injury caused by trauma, especially when both ligaments are torn.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presented in emergency department with elbow pain, and swelling in the hand and elbow. She was unable to move her elbow as it aggravated pain and swelling. Her pulse was also feeble. An X-Ray was performed as given below. Identify the vessel probably ruptured.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brachial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brachial artery is the most probable cause in this case, especially in the context of potential trauma. The other arteries are either not directly involved or less likely to cause the specific symptoms presented.
  • ➤ Brachial artery is the most probable cause in this case, especially in the context of potential trauma.
  • ➤ The other arteries are either not directly involved or less likely to cause the specific symptoms presented.

questions.text: All the following are causes of avascular necrosis of the femoral head except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Unmatched Blood Transfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unmatched blood transfusion does not relate to the mechanisms that lead to avascular necrosis of the femoral head. In contrast, options A), B), and C) all represent known risk factors for AVN, with A) and B) being well-established causes, while C) relates to general bone health rather than directly causing AVN.
  • ➤ Unmatched blood transfusion does not relate to the mechanisms that lead to avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
  • ➤ In contrast, options A), B), and C) all represent known risk factors for AVN, with A) and B) being well-established causes, while C) relates to general bone health rather than directly causing AVN.

questions.text: Which statement is True about pathological fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture in normal bone due to increased intensity of unacclimatized activity

options.label: B
options.text: Fracture in normal bone due to increased duration of unacclimatized activity

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture in weak bone by trivial trauma

questions.correct_answer: C. Fracture in weak bone by trivial trauma
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fracture in weak bone by trivial trauma is the definition of a pathological fracture, where a weakened bone fractures due to minimal trauma.
  • ➤ Fracture in weak bone by trivial trauma is the definition of a pathological fracture, where a weakened bone fractures due to minimal trauma.

questions.text: Serum alkaline phosphate is normal in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serum alkaline phosphatase is typically normal in multiple myeloma due to the absence of significant osteoblastic activity associated with the disease. In contrast, osteosarcoma and osteomalacia are characterized by elevated ALP levels, and malnutrition can lead to variable ALP levels, but it’s most likely to be normal in the context of multiple myeloma.
  • ➤ Serum alkaline phosphatase is typically normal in multiple myeloma due to the absence of significant osteoblastic activity associated with the disease.
  • ➤ In contrast, osteosarcoma and osteomalacia are characterized by elevated ALP levels, and malnutrition can lead to variable ALP levels, but it’s most likely to be normal in the context of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: What will be the ideal treatment for closed displaced fracture of lower third of fibula with fracture of medial malleolus. Sharp ends were seen at fracture site with soft tissue swelling of leg on X-ray. What will be its management?

options.label: C
options.text: Neurological Assessment – closed reduction – neurological assessment – analgesic – cast

questions.correct_answer: C. Neurological Assessment – closed reduction – neurological assessment – analgesic – cast
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neurological Assessment – closed reduction – neurological assessment – analgesic – cast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurological assessment followed by closed reduction and again performing the neurological assessment, followed by analgesics and cast application ensures comprehensive care.
  • ➤ Neurological assessment followed by closed reduction and again performing the neurological assessment, followed by analgesics and cast application ensures comprehensive care.

questions.text: A mother came to the OPD with her newborn baby with deformity of the feet as shown in the image. What is most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Manipulation & Cast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a 2-year-old child with a deformity of the feet, if the condition is clubfoot, the initial treatment of choice is manipulation followed by casting. It is non-invasive and effective when initiated early.
  • ➤ For a 2-year-old child with a deformity of the feet, if the condition is clubfoot, the initial treatment of choice is manipulation followed by casting.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with history of pathological fracture of neck of femur. She has elevated ALP and N-telopeptide. Her DEXA scan confirmed a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Which of the following would be raised?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) gets elevated in conditions with increased osteoclast activity and bone resorption, such as osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) gets elevated in conditions with increased osteoclast activity and bone resorption, such as osteoporosis.

questions.text: In a patient with gouty arthritis, strongly birefringent needle-shaped crystals with negative elongation in synovial fluid aspiration are composed of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Monosodium Urate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In gouty arthritis, the classic finding on synovial fluid analysis is: Needle-shaped crystals Negatively birefringent under polarized light Show yellow colour when aligned parallel to the slow axis (negative elongation)

  • ➤ In gouty arthritis, the classic finding on synovial fluid analysis is:
  • ➤ Needle-shaped crystals Negatively birefringent under polarized light Show yellow colour when aligned parallel to the slow axis (negative elongation)
  • ➤ Needle-shaped crystals
  • ➤ Negatively birefringent under polarized light
  • ➤ Show yellow colour when aligned parallel to the slow axis (negative elongation)
  • ➤ These crystals are composed of monosodium urate. Quick Crystal Comparison:

questions.text: A young lady after intense workout, lifting heavy weights, presents to you with lower backache involving right hip and radiating to right ankle. MRI shows the following finding. What nerve root is likely to get involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ L5 Nerve Root causes pain radiating to the hip, lateral leg, and foot (including the ankle) and is associated with weakness in dorsiflexion and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot.
  • ➤ L5 Nerve Root causes pain radiating to the hip, lateral leg, and foot (including the ankle) and is associated with weakness in dorsiflexion and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought with left hand pain. He was evaluated in casualty 2 weeks ago after falling on outstretched hand and X-ray of the hand was normal and discharged with a splint. Now on examination, there is tenderness of the anatomic snuffbox. Repeat x-ray of left hand is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Osteonecrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteonecrosis, can occur following a scaphoid fracture that compromises the bone's blood supply, leading to avascular necrosis.
  • ➤ Osteonecrosis, can occur following a scaphoid fracture that compromises the bone's blood supply, leading to avascular necrosis.

questions.text: A patient has sustained a pelvic fracture in an RTA, is bleeding and is in shock. Immediate management for this case should be:

options.label: D
options.text: Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis

questions.correct_answer: D. Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis is correct immediate management as it helps to compress the pelvis, reduce haemorrhage, and stabilize the fracture temporarily until definitive treatment can be provided.
  • ➤ Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis is correct immediate management as it helps to compress the pelvis, reduce haemorrhage, and stabilize the fracture temporarily until definitive treatment can be provided.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar presents with brown discolouration of teeth as shown in the image. What can be the most likely finding in the skeletal radiographs of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Osteosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteosclerosis may account for the increased density in bone and associated dental abnormalities, which can manifest as discoloration of teeth. However, it's also important to consider that various conditions affecting bone metabolism can influence dental appearance, and the specific etiology would need to be clarified further with clinical details and investigation results.
  • ➤ Osteosclerosis may account for the increased density in bone and associated dental abnormalities, which can manifest as discoloration of teeth.
  • ➤ However, it's also important to consider that various conditions affecting bone metabolism can influence dental appearance, and the specific etiology would need to be clarified further with clinical details and investigation results.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with a mushroom-like tumour in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features will help the clinician to identify a malignant transformation?

options.label: A
options.text: Initially growth of the tumour was away from the joint, now tumour growth is towards the joint

options.label: B
options.text: Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm

options.label: C
options.text: Tumour does not have malignant transformation

options.label: D
options.text: Tumour is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm is the most important and concerning sign of malignant transformation, especially when it exceeds 1 cm, and particularly when it reaches 2 cm. It suggests the possibility of chondrosarcoma.
  • ➤ Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm is the most important and concerning sign of malignant transformation, especially when it exceeds 1 cm, and particularly when it reaches 2 cm.
  • ➤ It suggests the possibility of chondrosarcoma.

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Shin splint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shin splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.
  • ➤ Shin splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

questions.text: Tom-Smith Arthritis is:

options.label: A
options.text: Septic arthritis of hip in adults

options.label: B
options.text: Septic arthritis of hip in infants

options.text: Rheumatoid arthritis of knee in adults

options.text: Rheumatoid arthritis of knee in infants

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Septic arthritis of hip in infants

  • ➤ Tom-Smith arthritis is a term used to describe septic arthritis of the hip in infants.
  • ➤ Tom-Smith arthritis is a term used to describe septic arthritis of the hip in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most convenient method for treatment of fracture shaft femur in children less than 2 years of age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spica Casting is the most appropriate, non-invasive, and convenient method of treatment. It provides sufficient immobilization and allows the bone to heal effectively with minimal risk of complications.
  • ➤ Spica Casting is the most appropriate, non-invasive, and convenient method of treatment.

questions.text: Supracondylar fracture of the femur commonly injures which structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Popliteal Vessel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While the popliteal nerve can also be injured, the risk of vascular injury, particularly to the popliteal artery and vein, is a significant concern due to the fracture's location and the potential for complications such as ischemia. Prompt recognition and management of any vascular injury are critical to prevent serious outcomes.Bottom of Form
  • ➤ While the popliteal nerve can also be injured, the risk of vascular injury, particularly to the popliteal artery and vein, is a significant concern due to the fracture's location and the potential for complications such as ischemia.
  • ➤ Prompt recognition and management of any vascular injury are critical to prevent serious outcomes.Bottom of Form

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What is the next the next step of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

options.label: D
options.text: Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction

questions.correct_answer: A. Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability can often restore alignment and function without the need for immediate surgery. Further imaging, such as a CT scan, may be necessary for complex fractures, but closed reduction is typically the first step.
  • ➤ Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability can often restore alignment and function without the need for immediate surgery.
  • ➤ Further imaging, such as a CT scan, may be necessary for complex fractures, but closed reduction is typically the first step.

questions.text: HRA with Austin-Moore prosthesis is done for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patient > 65 years old

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Austin-Moore prosthesis is typically used for elderly patients (over 65 years) with femoral neck fractures or certain hip fractures where preservation of the femoral head is not feasible. It is not commonly used for younger patients or for fractures like intertrochanteric or pertrochanteric fractures unless there are specific complications or poor bone quality. The goal in older patients is often to improve pain relief and mobility, which the Austin-Moore prosthesis can achieve.
  • ➤ The Austin-Moore prosthesis is typically used for elderly patients (over 65 years) with femoral neck fractures or certain hip fractures where preservation of the femoral head is not feasible.
  • ➤ It is not commonly used for younger patients or for fractures like intertrochanteric or pertrochanteric fractures unless there are specific complications or poor bone quality.
  • ➤ The goal in older patients is often to improve pain relief and mobility, which the Austin-Moore prosthesis can achieve.

questions.text: Injury to which region may result in paraplegia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thoracic spine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injuries to the thoracic spine most directly result in paraplegia, as they affect the nerve pathways responsible for controlling the lower limbs.
  • ➤ Injuries to the thoracic spine most directly result in paraplegia, as they affect the nerve pathways responsible for controlling the lower limbs.

questions.text: What is the test being performed in neglected traumatic dislocation of hip?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telescopy test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telescopy test is a key test for neglected traumatic hip dislocations, where it reveals abnormal femoral head movement due to the dislocation.Bottom of Form
  • ➤ Telescopy test is a key test for neglected traumatic hip dislocations, where it reveals abnormal femoral head movement due to the dislocation.Bottom of Form

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is commonly seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cubitus Valgus Deformity

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cubitus valgus is the deformity most commonly associated with tardy ulnar nerve palsy due to its effect on the ulnar nerve's course and tension at the elbow.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand. X-ray showed the following image. What can be a probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Colles fracture

questions.text: A patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion?
questions.correct_answer: A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.
  • ➤ On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

questions.text: Knuckle bender splint is used for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The knuckle bender splint is used to prevent or manage the clawing of the fingers, maintain functional positioning of the hand, and improve overall hand function. It is not typically used for the other nerve palsies, which require different types of splints and orthotics based on the specific muscles and joints involved.
  • ➤ The knuckle bender splint is used to prevent or manage the clawing of the fingers, maintain functional positioning of the hand, and improve overall hand function.
  • ➤ knuckle bender splint
  • ➤ It is not typically used for the other nerve palsies, which require different types of splints and orthotics based on the specific muscles and joints involved.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct regarding biopsy of malignant bone tumors? Always done by transverse incision. Sample should be taken from 2 different planes. Sample should be taken before any radiological investigations. Sample should be taken from periphery and not from necrotic centre.

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.correct_answer: C. b and d are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incision type depends on the location and size of the tumor, as well as the surgeon's preference. It could be longitudinal, transverse, or a combination. Taking samples from multiple planes increases the chances of obtaining representative tissue for accurate diagnosis. It helps to assess the tumor's depth, extent, and histological features. Radiological investigations like X-rays, CT scans, or MRIs are crucial for accurate localization and assessment of the tumor's extent before biopsy. These imaging studies help guide the biopsy procedure. The periphery of the tumor typically contains viable tumor cells, which are more representative of the tumor's biological behavior. Necrotic centers may not provide accurate information about the tumor's characteristics.
  • ➤ The incision type depends on the location and size of the tumor, as well as the surgeon's preference. It could be longitudinal, transverse, or a combination.
  • ➤ Taking samples from multiple planes increases the chances of obtaining representative tissue for accurate diagnosis. It helps to assess the tumor's depth, extent, and histological features.
  • ➤ Radiological investigations like X-rays, CT scans, or MRIs are crucial for accurate localization and assessment of the tumor's extent before biopsy. These imaging studies help guide the biopsy procedure.
  • ➤ The periphery of the tumor typically contains viable tumor cells, which are more representative of the tumor's biological behavior. Necrotic centers may not provide accurate information about the tumor's characteristics.

questions.text: Periosteal reaction in a case of acute osteomyelitis can be seen earliest at:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 10 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute osteomyelitis, the periosteal reaction typically appears around 10 days, which is the earliest visible sign on radiographs. This is due to the body's inflammatory response to the infection, which starts at this time and is visible on imaging as new bone formation or thickening of the periosteum.
  • ➤ In acute osteomyelitis, the periosteal reaction typically appears around 10 days, which is the earliest visible sign on radiographs.
  • ➤ This is due to the body's inflammatory response to the infection, which starts at this time and is visible on imaging as new bone formation or thickening of the periosteum.

questions.text: Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years are: Capsulotomy Femoral osteotomy Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a → c → b → d

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhoea 2 weeks back, followed by swollen, red and erythematous joints. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Shigella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella. This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema. It is commonly associated with HLA B27.
  • ➤ Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella.
  • ➤ This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema.
  • ➤ It is commonly associated with HLA B27.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cauda equina syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.
  • ➤ The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.

questions.text: Which of the following is the multifocal osteomyelitis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) SAPHO syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While SAPHO syndrome involves multifocal bone inflammation and can sometimes be confused with multifocal osteomyelitis.
  • ➤ While SAPHO syndrome involves multifocal bone inflammation and can sometimes be confused with multifocal osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Clay-Shoveler’s fracture is:

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture of spinous process of lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebra

options.label: B
options.text: Fracture of spinous process of mid thoracic vertebra

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of spinous process of lumbar vertebra

options.label: D
options.text: Spinous process fractures of lower cervical vertebrae

questions.correct_answer: A. Fracture of spinous process of lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebra
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fracture of spinous processes of lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebra

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clay-Shoveler’s fracture is specifically associated with fractures of the spinous processes of the lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae, usually C6-C7 or T1-T2.
  • ➤ Clay-Shoveler’s fracture is specifically associated with fractures of the spinous processes of the lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae, usually C6-C7 or T1-T2.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with a history of vertebral crush fractures presents to the OPD. Which of the following investigations is most useful to assess the extent of her osteoporosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DEXA Scan is the most useful investigation for assessing the extent of osteoporosis as it directly measures bone mineral density, which is essential for diagnosing and evaluating the severity of osteoporosis.
  • ➤ DEXA Scan is the most useful investigation for assessing the extent of osteoporosis as it directly measures bone mineral density, which is essential for diagnosing and evaluating the severity of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A march fracture most frequently results from:
questions.correct_answer: C. Muscle fatigue from prolonged walking
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A march fracture is primarily caused by repetitive stress and muscle fatigue due to prolonged activities such as walking, marching, or running.
  • ➤ A march fracture is primarily caused by repetitive stress and muscle fatigue due to prolonged activities such as walking, marching, or running.

questions.text: All of the following are true about rickets except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypertonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertonia is not typically associated with this condition. Rickets primarily involves issues with bone mineralization and growth, leading to deformities and characteristic signs, but not increased muscle tone.
  • ➤ Hypertonia is not typically associated with this condition.
  • ➤ Rickets primarily involves issues with bone mineralization and growth, leading to deformities and characteristic signs, but not increased muscle tone.

questions.text: Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture. More common in males than females. 1-year mortality rate is 20-30%. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur. 1-year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.correct_answer: C. b and d are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males. Most common complication is malunion. 1-year mortality rate is 20-30%. 1-year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
  • ➤ Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • ➤ Most common complication is malunion.
  • ➤ 1-year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • ➤ 1-year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

questions.text: What is the most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young individuals is the tendency of recurrent shoulder dislocation.
  • ➤ The most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young individuals is the tendency of recurrent shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: The earliest radiological sign in Pott’s disease is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Narrowing of intervertebral disc space
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Narrowing of intervertebral disc space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest radiological sign of Pott's disease is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space . This sign occurs due to the initial infection and inflammation in the disc space before more advanced features like vertebral erosion or collapse develop.
  • ➤ The earliest radiological sign of Pott's disease is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space .
  • ➤ narrowing of the intervertebral disc space
  • ➤ This sign occurs due to the initial infection and inflammation in the disc space before more advanced features like vertebral erosion or collapse develop.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed as a case of supraspinatus tendinitis. What degrees and what movement of shoulder would be painful?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 60°

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 60 degrees of abduction is the most painful range for patients with supraspinatus tendinitis because at this angle, the tendon is most likely to be impinged between the humeral head and the acromion, leading to pain and inflammation.
  • ➤ 60 degrees
  • ➤ the most painful range
  • ➤ supraspinatus tendinitis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common muscle to be congenitally absent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pectoralis major

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies. The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.
  • ➤ While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies.
  • ➤ The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.

questions.text: Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of which surgery?

options.label: D
options.text: Bicondylar plating of proximal tibia fracture

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total knee replacement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of Total Knee replacement surgery.
  • ➤ Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of Total Knee replacement surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of sudden increase in pain in osteochondroma, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Degenerative changes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Degenerative changes are a gradual process and are less likely to cause a sudden increase in pain compared to complications like sarcomatous change, fracture, or bursitis, which can result in more immediate and severe symptoms.
  • ➤ Degenerative changes are a gradual process and are less likely to cause a sudden increase in pain compared to complications like sarcomatous change, fracture, or bursitis, which can result in more immediate and severe symptoms.

questions.text: Most vascular zone of the bone is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metaphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most vascular zone of the bone is the metaphysis.
  • ➤ The most vascular zone of the bone is the metaphysis.

questions.text: All are seen in anterior shoulder dislocation except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Elevated anterior axillary fold

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the anterior shoulder dislocation, the anterior axillary fold is at a lower level. The Dugas and Hamilton ruler tests are positive. There is an increased vertical circumference of the axilla as compared to the normal side – Callaway’s test.
  • ➤ In the anterior shoulder dislocation, the anterior axillary fold is at a lower level.
  • ➤ The Dugas and Hamilton ruler tests are positive.
  • ➤ There is an increased vertical circumference of the axilla as compared to the normal side – Callaway’s test.

questions.text: A patient presenting with multiple humeral shaft fracture, following which he had difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm. He also complaints of loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm. Which nerve is damaged?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Musculocutaneous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm, with loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm are the symptoms associated with musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • ➤ Difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm, with loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm are the symptoms associated with musculocutaneous nerve injury.

questions.text: Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus is:

options.label: A
options.text: Extensor and ulnar deviator of the wrist

options.label: B
options.text: Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist

options.label: C
options.text: Injured in posterior interosseous nerve injury

questions.correct_answer: B. Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor and radial deviator of the wrist.
  • ➤ Extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor and radial deviator of the wrist.

questions.text: Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prepatellar bursa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Housemaid’s knee is caused by the inflammation in the prepatellar bursa. It causes pain in the front of the knee. Inflammation in other bursa of the knee causes pain above, below or anteromedial to the knee.
  • ➤ Housemaid’s knee is caused by the inflammation in the prepatellar bursa. It causes pain in the front of the knee.
  • ➤ Inflammation in other bursa of the knee causes pain above, below or anteromedial to the knee.

questions.text: Mic 2 positive cells are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ewing's sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MIC2 is a specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • ➤ MIC2 is a specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma.

questions.text: Poor prognostic sign for Ewing’s sarcoma is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fever is considered a poor prognostic sign due to its association with severe systemic symptoms or complications that could reflect more advanced disease or treatment challenges. However, traditionally, prognosis is more directly influenced by factors like age, tumour grade, and presence of metastases.
  • ➤ Fever is considered a poor prognostic sign due to its association with severe systemic symptoms or complications that could reflect more advanced disease or treatment challenges.
  • ➤ However, traditionally, prognosis is more directly influenced by factors like age, tumour grade, and presence of metastases.

questions.text: Bone resorption is inhibited by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estrogen is the hormone that inhibits bone resorption by decreasing osteoclast activity and preserving bone mass. In contrast, parathyroid hormone, thyroid hormones (in excess), and cortisol generally increase bone resorption.
  • ➤ Estrogen is the hormone that inhibits bone resorption by decreasing osteoclast activity and preserving bone mass.
  • ➤ In contrast, parathyroid hormone, thyroid hormones (in excess), and cortisol generally increase bone resorption.

questions.text: Muscle with intra-articular tendon is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Popliteus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Out of the given options, popliteus muscle tendon is the intra-articular tendon. Long head of biceps also has an intra-articular tendon.
  • ➤ Out of the given options, popliteus muscle tendon is the intra-articular tendon.
  • ➤ Long head of biceps also has an intra-articular tendon.

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature
  • ➤ Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: Pain in Paget’s disease is relieved best by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Calcitonin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are drug of choice and calcitonin is used to relieve pain.

questions.text: Light bulb sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of shoulder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The light bulb sign is a radiological feature seen in posterior dislocation of the shoulder . It is characterized by the humeral head appearing rounded and bulbous due to its position and internal rotation, distinguishing it from other shoulder injuries and conditions.
  • ➤ The light bulb sign is a radiological feature seen in posterior dislocation of the shoulder .
  • ➤ light bulb sign
  • ➤ posterior dislocation of the shoulder
  • ➤ It is characterized by the humeral head appearing rounded and bulbous due to its position and internal rotation, distinguishing it from other shoulder injuries and conditions.

questions.text: A patient present with hip pain and true shortening of the limb which was diagnosed as tuberculosis of the hip. Which stage of the disease is he currently in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stage of advanced arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TB arthritis start as synovitis, then progress to periarticular osteopenia and marginal erosion, and end up with joint destruction. Patients usually have mild, local and constitutional symptoms. In the stage of advanced arthritis, the patient presents with flexion, adduction & internal rotation of the affected hip with >1 cm of true shortening.
  • ➤ TB arthritis start as synovitis, then progress to periarticular osteopenia and marginal erosion, and end up with joint destruction. Patients usually have mild, local and constitutional symptoms.
  • ➤ In the stage of advanced arthritis, the patient presents with flexion, adduction & internal rotation of the affected hip with >1 cm of true shortening.

questions.text: While attending to a victim of RTA, who is otherwise conscious, all the following can be done except:

options.label: A
options.text: Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board

options.label: B
options.text: Strap the patient’s head, thorax & pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position

options.label: C
options.text: Turn the patient to one side

options.label: D
options.text: Assess the patient by asking his name

questions.correct_answer: C. Turn the patient to one side
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Turn the patient to one side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turning the patient to one side is contraindicated because it can cause movement of the spine and may worsen any potential spinal injury.
  • ➤ Turning the patient to one side is contraindicated because it can cause movement of the spine and may worsen any potential spinal injury.

questions.text: A patient came to emergency room with complaint of sciatica. You lifted the leg of the patient by flexing the hip. This resulted in pain going down the back of leg. Pain was relieved as the leg was lowered by flexing the knee. The clinical test is being performed is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laseague’s sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lasegue's sign is a clinical test used to assess for sciatica or nerve root irritation, where pain radiates down the back of the leg when the leg is raised, and it is relieved when the knee is flexed.
  • ➤ Lasegue's sign is a clinical test used to assess for sciatica or nerve root irritation, where pain radiates down the back of the leg when the leg is raised, and it is relieved when the knee is flexed.

questions.text: The patient who had previously suffered a fracture in his right leg, visited the doctor for a follow-up appointment during which the cast was removed for evaluation. The doctor observed that the area had become malleable but was not movable, leading to reapplication of the cast. Based on this assessment, what is the stage of fracture healing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Soft callus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely stage of fracture healing in this scenario, where the fracture site is malleable but not movable, is the soft callus stage, where healing has begun but the bone is not yet fully rigid.
  • ➤ The most likely stage of fracture healing in this scenario, where the fracture site is malleable but not movable, is the soft callus stage, where healing has begun but the bone is not yet fully rigid.

questions.text: A patient woke up in the morning with an inability to extend digits. The rest of the sensory and motor examination of hand was normal. Which nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior interosseous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of posterior interosseous nerve injury.
  • ➤ The given clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of posterior interosseous nerve injury.
